title: 105_s494
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" and includes provisions for prisoner copayments for health care services. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" introduces prisoner copayments for health care services, defining terms like account, Director, health care provider, health care visit, and prisoner. The "Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act" defines a prisoner as someone subject to incarceration, detention, or admission to a facility for violations of criminal law. A qualified health care visit excludes certain types of visits like those during intake, annual exams, emergencies, immunizations, or initiated by health care staff. The Director shall assess and collect a fee of $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit, excluding certain types of visits like emergencies, immunizations, or those initiated by health care staff. Prisoners who are under 18, pregnant, seriously mentally ill, or permanently disabled are exempt from copayments. The Director will collect fees ranging from $3 to $5 for each qualified health care visit, prescription medication, and visits resulting from prisoner-inflicted injuries. The fees will be collected from the prisoner's account. Each fee assessed for health care visits or prescription medication will be collected from the prisoner's account. Fees will be collected on the date of the visit or through an installment payment plan if the account balance is insufficient. The Director will establish an installment payment plan for prisoners to pay fees for health care visits or medication. Treatment cannot be refused due to financial reasons. Amounts collected will be deposited into the Crime Victims' Fund. The Director must report to Congress annually on the implementation of the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act. The Director will report annually to Congress on the amounts collected and effects of the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act on prisoners' health care visits. Prisoner copayments for health care services are required under the Federal Prisoner Health Care Copayment Act. The Director will provide annual reports to Congress on the amounts collected and the impact on prisoners' health care visits.
